title: Singing in tune
intro: The act of singing is a very complex skill, involving a huge number of processes in our bodies and brains. Neil and Georgina discuss singing and how it’s not essential to sing in tune to benefit from doing it.
this_week_question: What is the meaning of ‘karaoke’? Is it...
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: unable to sing tunes accurately or recognise different notes
pair of folds in the throat that move backwards and forwards when air from the lungs moves over them
organ between the nose and the lungs that contains the vocal cords; otherwise known as the voice box
the human body's reaction to anything that disturbs its internal balance, for example pain, infection, fear or exercise
used to encourage someone to continue doing something

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: And I’m Georgina.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: [Singing badly] DO, RE, MI, FA, SOL, LA, TI, DO !

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Neil! What are you doing?! Please stop!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, hi Georgina! I’m practising my singing. I’m going to do virtual karaoke tonight with some friends!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Karaoke?! – really, Neil?! I heard you singing at the Christmas party and to be honest I think you might be tone deaf – you know, you can’t sing in tune.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Me? Tone deaf?! I’m a nightingale! Listen: DO RE MIIII !

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Between you and me, I think Neil is a bit tone deaf ! Wait until I tell him singing is the subject of this programme.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I heard that, Georgina! And I’m glad this programme is about singing because I love it and what I lack in ability, I make up for in enthusiasm!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: I’m sure your karaoke buddies would agree with you, Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That reminds me of my quiz question, Georgina. As you know, I love karaoke - meeting up with friends to sing the words of our favourite pop songs over a musical backing track. Karaoke was invented in Japan and its name is a combination of different Japanese words – but what words? What is the meaning of ‘karaoke’? Is it:

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Well, after listening to you sing, Neil, I’m tempted to say b), angry cat, but that would be mean, so I’ll guess, a) machine voice.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Georgina. I’ll take that as a compliment. But however good - or bad - my singing may be, there’s no doubt that the act of singing itself is a very complex skill, involving a huge number of processes in our bodies and brains. So what happens physically when we sing a musical note?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Usually something unexpected in your case, Neil! So here’s Marijke Peters, presenter of BBC World Service programme, CrowdScience, to explain exactly what happens when we open our mouths to sing.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Listen out for the different body parts Marijke mentions:

transcript.author: Marijke Peters
transcript.text: Vocal folds, also called vocal cords , are crucial here. They’re two flaps of skin stretched across your larynx that vibrate when you sing and create a sound. The pitch of that sound, how high or low it is, depends on the frequency of their vibration, so if you want to hit the right note they need to be working properly.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Important body parts needed to sing include the vocal cords - a pair of folds in the throat that move backwards and forwards when air from the lungs moves over them.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The vocal chords are stretched over the larynx - also known as the voice box, it’s the organ between the nose and the lungs containing the vocal folds.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Singing is similar to what happens when you play a guitar. The vocal cords act like the guitar strings to produce a buzz or vibration – a continuous and quick shaking movement.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: They vibrate over the larynx which, like the body of a guitar, amplifies the sound.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: So why do some people (Neil!) find it hard to sing in tune? Is it because they cannot physically reproduce sounds? Or because they hear sounds differently from the rest of us?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, according to psychology professor, Peter Pfordresher, it’s neither. He thinks that for poor singers the problem is generally not in the ears or voice, but in their brains – specifically the connection between sound perception and muscle movement.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: So there’s no hope for you?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Not necessarily. Here’s Professor Pfordresher encouraging the listeners of BBC World Service’s, CrowdScience:

transcript.author: Peter Pfordresher
transcript.text: I think there’s reason for you to be hopeful and however accurate or inaccurate your singing is, one recommendation I would have for you is to keep singing because there is evidence that singing itself, whether accurate or inaccurate, has benefits socially and also for stress responses , so good reason for you to keep it up!

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Whether you’re tone deaf or pitch perfect, there’s lots of evidence for the health benefits of singing.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: For one, singing strengthens your stress responses . Otherwise known as ‘fight or flight’, stress responses are the human body’s reaction to external threats that cause an imbalance, for example pain, infection or fear.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: From operatic Pavarottis to enthusiastic karaoke fans, Professor Pfordresher thinks singers should keep it up – a phrase used to encourage someone to continue doing something. So, Neil, maybe you should keep singing, after all!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You’ve changed you tune, Georgina! Maybe you’d like to come with me to karaoke next time we’re allowed out?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Hmm, I think some practice would be a good idea, but first let’s return to the quiz question. You asked me about the meaning of the Japanese word karaoke…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right. Does karaoke mean, a) machine voice, b) angry cat, or c) empty orchestra? What did you say?

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: I said a) machine voice.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Which was… the wrong answer! Karaoke actually means c) empty orchestra, or in other words, music that has the melody missing.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: Well, that’s better than an angry cat, I guess! Let’s recap the vocabulary starting with tone deaf – a way to describe someone who cannot sing in tune or hear different sounds.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Like playing a guitar string, singers use their vocal cords – a pair of folds in the throat that are stretched over the larynx , or voice box, another part of the throat, to produce a sound vibration - a quick, shaking movement.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: No matter how good or bad a singer you are, singing is good for your stress responses – the ‘fight or flight’ mechanism your body uses to regain inner balance.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So no matter what Georgina thinks about my singing, I’m going to keep it up – a phrase used to encourage someone to continue their good performance.

transcript.author: Georgina
transcript.text: That’s all from us. Keep singing and join us again soon at 6 Minute English. Don’t forget we also have a free app you can download from the app stores. Bye!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye!
